articles.title: Mapping Burns and Natural Reforestation using Thematic Mapper Data
articles.authors: Lopez Garcia, M., and V. Caselles
articles.link:
When it comes to detecting and mapping forest fires, remote sensing methods are unparalleled.\
        The paper utilized Landsat 5 (TM) data to analyze forest-fire events in Valencia (Spain) and track the recovery of vegetation in these regions.\
        The degree of the fire's effect on the surrounding forest was measured in comparison to a reference region that had not been affected by the fire.\
        The best parameters for mapping fire damage were the thermal band radiance and the normalized difference in reflectance between the near IR  and middle IR.\
        The index also helped in tracking vegetation regrowth after fires.\
        After a month of burn, the burnt areas had 5 to 6 degrees Celsius higher than those in the reference region, and the vegetation index has negative values where it was positive before the blaze.\
        However, with time, as vegetation grows, the differences between the burnt and the unburnt areas diminishes.

articles.title: Landscape Assessment: Remote Sensing of Severity, the Normalized Burn Ratio; and Ground Measure of Severity, the Composite Burn Index.
articles.authors: Key, C. and N. Benson, N
articles.link:
The primary goal of a Landscape Assessment is to detect and quantify the impacts of fire over wide regions, sometimes including many burns.\
         The approach concentrated on comparing outcomes and collecting data over large geographic areas and time periods.\
         The results demonstrated the regional variability of burns and the dynamic relationship between fire, vegetation, and terrain.\
         The 'burnt index', defined as a scaled index to measure the extent of ecological damages brought by fire, was mapped and quantified in the study.\
         The methodology comprised of two combined approaches.\
         The former included burnt remote sensing and deriving the normalized burn ratio (NBR) at two different time frames using Landsat imagery.\
         The latter included vegetation rehabilitation potential and delay in its mortality.\
         Also, a supplementary field sampling method, the Composite Burn Index (CBI), was introduced which demonstrated multple advantages and benefits.
